text: there are 446 bridges in the city of
Pittsburgh that's more than any other
city in the world about 20% of those
bridges are considered structure
deficient the other 80% are in in fairly
good condition the steel is manufactured
right here and now the steel mills are
gone but the bridges still continue
there my main source of income first of
all and they are the way that you move
around this city the bridges in
Pittsburgh are not only functional
they're beautiful I can't go over one
without marveling at the construction or
something or what's gone on or what's
behind the bridge
that's the Allegheny River it starts in
upstate New York and flows all the way
down to here the point it's called to
the right is the Monongahela River it
flows from West Virginia all the way
down to the point and where the two
rivers the Allegheny and Monongahela
come together they form the Ohio River
which starts here in Pittsburgh and
flows all the way down to the
Mississippi looking up further you can
just see the piers is a little hazy of
the Birmingham Bridge
it's a 19 span structure just over 4,000
feet long
it's a 20 million dollar rehabilitation
project and it's one of the the first
ones that we've seen in quite a while
that's been over ten million dollars we
use local unions for the crafts it also
created a lot of opportunities for our
subcontractors a lot of these craftsmen
have been around for many many years
they're a lot of older people that have
worked on the structures when they were
being built or still are involved in
some of these rehabilitations and so
they take a lot of pride in the fact
that they're there maintaining these
structures back to the what they were
when we first build them here in
Pittsburgh probably 3/4 of the
population would look at that and go
there's no way I'm ever going up there
so if you are afraid of heights
if you don't like hot weather if you
don't like cold weather if you don't
want to work hard you're not going to
succeed in this business it takes a
certain kind of guy a paint mixer in the
summer and a runner in the women good
money long hours no but I like it it's
hard to find a lot of good people to
come out on bridges like this and stay
out here on a day like today people
don't build bridges governments build
bridges we're actually in a period now
where they have passed the highway bill
and we are going to have more work than
we've ever had historically the benefits
from it are probably going to begin
right around the new year we're
considering taking on more apprentices
than we normally do just so that we can
start Manning these jobs
you're up on top of Mount Washington you
look out you can see to the rivers and
you can see the bridges just going one
after the other away from each other and
and the skyline of the city and it is a
beautiful view
it makes Pittsburgh singular
